message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being considered is likely to be a bile acid sequestrant, which can cause fat malabsorption as a side effect. Gallstones are not common but can be a side effect of long-term treatment. Acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not associated with this type of medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being referred to is likely a bile acid sequestrant, which works by binding to bile acids in the intestine, leading to increased excretion of bile acids and increased demand for the liver to produce more, leading to consumption of circulating LDL-cholesterol. One of the potential adverse effects of this medication is fat malabsorption, which can lead to diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Gallstones are a potential adverse effect of another class of cholesterol-lowering medications (fibrates). Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition associated with insulin resistance and obesity, but is not an adverse effect of this medication. Facial flushing is a potential adverse effect of niacin (another cholesterol-lowering medication).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being described is likely a bile acid sequestrant, which works by binding to bile acids in the intestine, forcing the liver to use cholesterol to make more bile acids. This can lead to fat malabsorption, which can cause digestive symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and bloating. Gallstones can also be a possible complication of long-term use of bile acid sequestrants, but it is less common than fat malabsorption. Acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not typically associated with this class of medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being referred to is likely a bile acid sequestrant. One of the common side effects of this medication is fat malabsorption, which can lead to steatorrhea (oily stool) and other gastrointestinal symptoms. Gallstones are also a potential side effect but are less common. Acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not associated with this medication.

This can lead to fat malabsorption and potential bowel disturbances. Gallstones may also be a potential adverse effect, but fat malabsorption is a more immediate concern. Acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not commonly associated with this type of medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that forces the liver to consume cholesterol to make more bile salts is a bile acid sequestrant. The most common adverse effect is gastrointestinal, including fat malabsorption, which can lead to steatorrhea and nutrient deficiencies. Gallstones are a rare but possible adverse effect, while acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not associated with this medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being considered is likely a bile acid sequestrant, which can cause malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins and fatty acids. Other adverse effects, such as gallstones, acanthosis nigricans, and facial flushing, are not commonly associated with this medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication being considered is likely a bile acid sequestrant, which works by binding to bile acids in the intestine and preventing their reabsorption. This forces the liver to use cholesterol to make more bile salts, which decreases circulating LDL cholesterol levels. However, this can also lead to fat malabsorption, which can cause diarrhea and other gastrointestinal symptoms. The other options are less likely to be associated with this medication. Gallstones may develop with prolonged use of bile acid sequestrants, but they are not the highest risk adverse effect. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition associated with insulin resistance and usually resolves with weight loss. Facial flushing may be associated with niacin therapy, not bile acid sequestrants.

This medication works by binding bile acids in the intestine and preventing their reabsorption, thus forcing the liver to use cholesterol to make more bile salts. The main side effect of bile acid sequestrants is fat malabsorption, which can lead to diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gallstones are a potential complication of this medication, but the patient in this question is at higher risk of fat malabsorption. Acanthosis nigricans and facial flushing are not associated with bile acid sequestrants.

Gallstones are a potential complication of hyperlipidemia, but are not directly related to the medication being considered.
